posts.title: Netcompany - Lessons From My Early Developer Journey
posts.description: Starting out in tech isn’t easy, but full of lessons. From fixing my first bug to collaborating on global projects, balancing work-life challenges, and growing beyond coding, here’s how my early career shaped me.

contentBlocks.content: A Blank Page at the Start.

Everyone has a tough start in their career, and mine was no exception. When I first began, it truly felt like opening a blank page. I didn’t know much at the time, but I was fortunate to be guided and trained by some incredibly talented IT professionals. That made the beginning both challenging and memorable.

I still remember my very first task: fixing a small UI bug. What seemed simple at first turned into a whole learning journey. My lead spent almost an entire day walking me through each step, from setting up the environment, to understanding the project structure, deployment process, preparing reports, and even updating documentation. These were things I had never learned in university, but they became the foundation for everything that followed.
Beyond Just Development

At first, I thought being a developer was all about writing code. But I quickly realized the role goes far beyond that. My work soon expanded into areas like consulting with clients, reviewing pull requests, onboarding new teammates, analyzing problems, clarifying requirements, and troubleshooting issues.

There were days when I hardly wrote a single line of code, instead, I spent most of my time communicating with clients, supporting teammates, and assisting testers and QAs in their processes. Along the way, I had the chance to meet amazing people, both locally and globally, who set strong examples for me. Working with them taught me not just about technology, but also about professionalism, collaboration, and teamwork.
Learning from Big Projects

I was lucky enough to gain hands-on experience with large, global projects for different firms and industries at Netcompany. These weren’t small experiments, they were complex systems where I had to understand how different parts of the workflow connected.
Collaborating with international teams gave me the chance to observe different working styles and adopt new habits. One of the biggest lessons during this time was about work-life balance.

In the beginning, I often carried my work home with me, which is considered quite normal for many Vietnamese developers (and in some places around the world too). But my overseas teammates noticed and gently encouraged me to leave unfinished tasks for the next day. They showed me the importance of setting healthy boundaries and maintaining a sustainable rhythm. That advice stayed with me, and I believe it made me not only a better developer but also a happier one.
Mentoring, Growth, and Performance
Mentoring and performance reviews also played a big role in shaping my career. They gave me a mirror, and a clear set of criteria, to evaluate how I was performing and where I could improve.

Over time, I became more consistent in following coding standards, paying closer attention to detail, and delivering higher-quality results. On the technical side, my code became cleaner, more efficient, and aligned with clean code principles.

But the most noticeable growth was in my management skills. With constructive feedback from colleagues, I learned to deliver tasks on time, juggle multiple responsibilities, and approach both co-workers and clients with professionalism.
Looking Back

When I look back, I see a journey full of challenges, growth, and countless valuable lessons. I truly appreciate the time I spent at Netcompany, and I’m grateful for all the help I received along the way.
That foundation has shaped me into who I am today and given me the confidence to continue growing in my career. And as I look ahead, I’m excited about where the next chapters will take me.

posts.title: My First Business Trip: Lessons From a Training in Denmark
posts.description: One of the greatest benefits of joining Netcompany was the chance to attend regular training seminars and courses. These weren’t just check-the-box trainings, they genuinely made me a stronger developer.

contentBlocks.content: Among them, there’s one that stood out: a client training seminar in Denmark. Yes, all the way from Vietnam to Denmark! From the moment I received the invitation, I knew it would be a huge challenge, but also an incredible opportunity to see how big companies run successful IT projects.
The First Challenge: Jet Lag

This was my first time traveling such a long distance, and jet lag hit me hard. The time difference completely messed up my schedule, and I remember sitting in meetings while my body insisted it was the middle of the night.

But that was part of the lesson: business trips require preparation, professionalism, and discipline. You’re not just there for yourself, you’re representing your company. Being on time, showing up ready, and adapting quickly were all part of the experience.
Training Like a Real Project

Although this was “just” a training course, it felt like a real project from day one. We had a one-week timeframe to deliver results (almost impossible), and the schedule was packed with meetings, negotiations, and planning sessions.
Our team had to go through all phases of the Agile Software Development Life Cycle:
Meeting with clients to debate pricing, features, design, and deadlines
Building prototypes and demos
Negotiating trade-offs under tight deadlines
Meeting with clients to debate pricing, features, design, and deadlines
Handling user acceptance testing with a pushy client panel

I was surprised by how active and straightforward my international colleagues were during discussions. It was refreshing, and a little intimidating at first, to see such open debate, but I quickly adapted and learned from their style.
My Role: Front-End and Beyond

I was assigned as a front-end developer, which carried extra pressure. During client demos, the UI was the first thing they’d see. Even if the backend wasn’t fully functional, meaningful interfaces gave the impression of progress.
Besides UI, I also pitched in to support teammates:
Troubleshooting and integrating with backend systems.
Writing documentation and proposals.
Joining discussions and helping with problem-solving.
It wasn’t just about coding—it was about collaboration, professionalism, and showing up as a reliable teammate.
Beyond the Code

The training also focused on professionalism outside of work sessions. We had team bonding activities, outdoor exercises, and lessons on staying balanced under stress. Even something as simple as sharing meals with colleagues became a chance to learn how to behave professionally in a multicultural setting.

contentBlocks.title: A short break with team members, between the deadlines storm

contentBlocks.content: One memory that sticks with me is coding late into the night, except in Denmark, it was still daylight at 10 PM! Exhausted but motivated, our team pushed through, supporting each other until the very end.
The Outcome & Lessons Learned
In the end, our product wasn’t 100% complete or perfect, but our team earned the highest score among all groups. The feedback was overwhelmingly positive, and honestly, I hadn’t expected that.
Agile SDLC teaches you to adapt, but also shows that not everything is possible within tight deadlines.
Communication and negotiation are just as important as coding when it comes to project success.
Professionalism isn’t limited to meetings, it’s about how you carry yourself in every interaction.
Looking Back

That trip to Denmark was more than just a training, it was a milestone in my career. I learned how global teams work, how to stay professional under pressure, and how collaboration can make even impossible projects feel achievable.
